author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Sons and fans of Yogi Berra gather to celebrate his life
text:
KATHY WILLENS/AP New York Yankees special instructor Yogi Berra tips his cap to a crowd of admirers watching from the stands, Tuesday, March 22, 2005, at Legends Field in Tampa, Fla. It was the fans’ chance Sunday to bid farewell to Yankee legend Yogi Berra.
The Hall of Fame catcher’s son, Larry Berra, fought back tears as he thanked the hundreds of fans who lined up at Yogi Berra Museum at Montclair State University for a day of classic baseball footage, stories and family memories about the charismatic catcher who died Sept. 22.
“To me he was just dad, but to see you all here it's just overwhelming," Larry said. "The joy that has been presented by all you people has been amazing."
Larry hoped the adoration for his dad lasts forever.
Bill Denver/for New York Daily News Yogi Berra's three sons Larry (L), Dale (C) and Tim (R) speak to the fans that attended a Memorial Festivital to honor their father at the Yogi Berra Museum. “My favorite memory — every night at 11:30 p.m. I would watch ‘Seinfeld’ with him and we would sit and talk and watch baseball games. It was almost more like a friend than a dad,” Larry said, who later added “I just try to emulate him.”
Berra’s youngest son, Dale, recalled his dad coming home after a loss.
Dale asked his famous dad to play catch — and without missing a beat, Yogi said, “That’s why you got brothers.”
Bill Denver for New York Daily News Neil Van Ess, Commander of the New Jersey Division of the Military Order Of The Purple Heart, waits for the doors to open for memorial festivities to begin to honor Yogi Berra, the Hall Of Fame Baseball Player and Purple Heart Recipient at the Yogi Berra Museum in Little Falls, New Jersey. (Bill Denver For New York Daily News) Bill Denver/for New York Daily News Yogi Berra's hand prints in the sidewalk outside the Yogi Berra Museum on the campus of Montclair State University in Little Falls, New Jersey. Previous Next Enlarge Fan Mark Granieri, 51, wore an 1860s-era baseball uniform to the celebration.
“He was a man of the people. He was a World War II veteran. He was a cultural icon,” Granieri said. “Yogi’s legacy is his humanity.”
The beloved Yankee won three American League MVP awards and played on 10 World Series teams. He was 90.
Bill Denver/for New York Daily News Dressed up in their circa 19th Century Baseball Uniforms are Mark "Gaslight" Granieri, (L); Brad "Brooklyn" Shaw (C) and Danny "Batman" Shaw (R), all of Manalapan, New Jersey. Bill Denver/for New York Daily News Mike "1864" Liptangel, 68, of St. James, New York came to the memorial festivities to honor Yogi Berra, dressed as Babe Ruth. Previous Next Enlarge A private service was held last week for Berra with Timothy Cardinal Dolan presiding over a funeral Mass attended by a full roster of past and present pinstriped greats. Former Yankees manager Joe Torre gave the eulogy.
Susan Cole, Montclair State University president, said Berra charmed her the first time they met at a dinner.
He asked her numerous questions about what it was like to be president of a university.
Bill Denver/for New York Daily News Larry Berra, son of Yogi Berra pauses during the singing of "God Bless America" during the beginning Memorial Festivities to honor his dad Yogi Berra, held at the Yogi Berra Museum. “Well, it ain’t a bad job if you can’t play ball,” Cole recalled Berra saying.
Little Falls, N.J., Mayor Darlene Conti called Berra “a wonderful man who touched so many people with his humor and his character.”
She added one of Berra’s classic Quote: s.
Mel Evans/AP Larry Berra, son of New York Yankees Hall of Fame catcher Yogi Berra, is hugged by a well-wisher near a Yogi Berra statue during a public memorial tribute for his father at the Yogi Berra Museum. “I personally want to thank you for making this day necessary,” she said.
Berra’s granddaughter, Lindsay Berra, 37, said the family felt they needed to stage a public event for his many fans following his private funeral.
“There were so many people who loved him,” she said.
